== UEFI Testing ==

If you have access to a machine using EFI firmware (you can check by seeing if `/sys/firmware/efi` exists on your machine), then we'd appreciate some brief testing.

The test data we're looking for:

# '''Machine''' Basic identifying info (eg Intel Tunnel Mountain)
# '''UEFI Version''' Vendor and version (eg tiano core, v2.30)
<pre>
      dmesg | grep "EFI v"
</pre>
# '''CSM''': Was CSM (legacy BIOS compatibility mode) enabled for this test run? (yes/know/don't know)
# '''Boot''': Does it boot at all?
# '''Video''': Do all of GRUB, plymouth and X display correctly?
# '''S3''': `sudo fwts s3 --s3-multiple=30`
# '''S4''': `sudo fwts s4 --s4-multiple=30`
# '''S5 (shutdown)''': `sudo shutdown -P now`
# '''Reboot''': `sudo reboot`

If possible (especially if some of the above tests fail), record the fwts info:
## Memory layout: `fwts memmapdump -`
## EFI variables: `sudo fwts uefidump`
## MTRR config: `sudo fwts mtrr`
## Systab: `sudo cat /sys/firmware/efi/systab`
      I expect ACPI20 *and* SMBIOS to be configured. SMBIOS (containing the DMI tables) can be also be verified 
      using: `sudo fwts smbios -` and `sudo fwts dmi_decode -`

Testing should be done with and Oneric x86_64 image on USB. If possible, disable legacy BIOS compatibilty ("CSM") mode; this may be possible through the BIOS configuration screen, or you may be able to use a "CSM-off" build of your BIOS.

To install fwts in an Oneiric live USB image:
<pre>
    sudo add-apt-repository ppa:firmware-testing-team/ppa-fwts-stable
    sudo apt-get update
    sudo apt-get install fwts
</pre>
